Award.AwardTitle: Monolithic integrated-photonic sensors in the molecular fingerprint region

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is to develop a materials platform for mid-infrared integrated photonics and create mid-infrared photonic crystal sensors with parts per billion sensitivity. Such a platform and sensors do not currently exist. High sensitivity will be achieved by targeting strong fundamental vibrational absorption lines of chemical components in the mid-infrared spectral range, also known as the molecular fingerprint region, and employing the principle of slow light in slotted photonic crystal waveguides. The photonic crystal waveguides will be monolithically integrated with mid-infrared quantum cascade lasers and detectors using epitaxial transfer techniques to produce highly compact integrated-photonic chemical sensors operating in the mid-infrared spectral region for a wide range of applications, such as chemical and biomedical sensing, environmental monitoring, and security applications.

The scientific objective of this project to investigate a mid-infrared photonic waveguideing platform spanning molecular fingerprint region (3-14 micrometer) and develop integrated-photonic sensors in the molecular fingerprint region. Silicon-on-insulator devices cannot be operated beyond 3.5 micrometer wavelength range owing to mid-infrared absorption in SiO2, silicon-on-sapphire platform is limited to wavelengths below 5 micrometer owing to sapphire absorption, and silicon itself is only transparent down to 7-8 micrometers. The lack of a suitable photonic waveguiding platform currently limits the realization of a portable absorption spectrometer surrogate of benchtop infrared spectroscopic systems that can effectively probe the molecular fingerprint region below 1500 cm-1. Epitaxially-grown GaAs/AlGaAs waveguides offer a well-established lattice-matched, very low defect density and high index contrast platform for low loss optical circuits in the entire 3-14 micrometer wavelength range. This project aims at developing a GaAs/AlGaAs integrated photonics platform for on-chip mid-infrared photonics spanning the entire mid-infrared spectral range, including the molecular fingerprint region, and using this platform to demonstrate high sensitivity low parts per billion on-chip absorption sensing in the molecular fingerprint region. High sensitivity will be achieved using slotted photonic crystal waveguide devices. The proposed platform is expected to have a detection limit of 0.3 parts per billion for CO2 and 1 part per billion for toluene at their respective peak absorbance wavelengths at 4.23 micrometer and at 13.8 micrometer, respectively.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of this project a method is developed for monolithic integration of quantum cascade lasers (QCLs) and quantum cascade detectors (QCDs) with passive low-loss mid-infrared waveguides. A bandstructure design of QCLs was performed that can simultaneously perform as QCDs. Early efforts of developing of an integrated photonics platform focused on transfer-printing of QCLs to silicon-on-sapphire (SOS) and germanium-on-silicon (GOS) substrates. Successful transfer-printing and operation of QCLs on SOS was performed for the first time. Subsequently, a more promising method of monolithic integration of QCLs with InGaAs waveguides was pursued and the first operational photonic integration of QCLs with III-V waveguides was demonstrated for the first time.

Since the emission from the QCL is transverse magnetic (TM) polarized and 2-D slotted PCWs have photonic band gaps (PBGs) for transverse electric (TE) polarized propagating light only, in order to achieve the goal of a low low size, weight and power (SWaP) device and making an on-chip spectrometer by monolithically integrating the PCW, QCL and QCD, a polarization rotator to rotate TM-polarized light from QCL to TE-polarized light in the slotted PCW in silicon-on-sapphire at =4.55m was designed, fabricated and experimentally demonstrated. In order to cover the entire molecular fingerprint region, a single-step etched polarization rotator-splitter (PRS) in low index contrast InGaAs-InP material system at 6.15 μm was also designed, fabricated and experimentally demonstrated. This material system enables a bonding-free monolithic integration of  the passive low loss waveguide with the active InP QCDs and QCLs.

For gas sensing, a fully suspended InGaAs waveguide devices with holey photonic crystal waveguides and subwavelength grating cladding waveguides was designed and fabricated for mid-infrared sensing at λ = 6.15 μm in the InGaAs−InP platform. PPM-level detection of ammonia was experimentally demonstrated with both waveguides. This is the first demonstration of suspended InGaAs membrane waveguides in the InGaAs−InP platform at such a long wavelength with gas sensing. On an SOI platform a 2D holey photonic crystal waveguide was designed and optimized to operate at λ = 3.4 μm at the centre wavelength of 3.4μm which is a peak absorbance for ethanol. Utilizing this holey PCW the capability of sub parts per million level gas detection was experimentally demonstrated. Both sensors are readily scalable to other wavelengths enabling the detection of a myriad of gas species. Monolithic integration of presented passive and active devices developed over the course of this project paves the wave gor on-chip mid-IR photonic waveguide gas sensing platform with lower cost which will open a plethora of applications. The applicability of III-V semiconductor waveguides explored here can serve as a universal integrated photonic platform across the entire mid-IR spectral range, including the molecular fingerprint region. This III-V platform can also enable a wide range of other photonic-integrated circuit devices in mid-IR 3-14μm spectral range for beam combining, beam steering, and other applications.
